passages.text: Superior margins & returns at attractive valuation amid an industry upcycle; initiate at Buy
YAZG.SI 12m Price Target: \(\) 4.00\(Price:\) \ \(2.91\) Upside: \(37.3\%\)
We initiate on Yangzijiang with a Buy; 12m TP of SGD 4.00 implies \(37\%\) upside

Best positioned with cost advantages and superior returns: We categorize the ongoing upcycle into two stages: 1) earnings booming in 2025- 28E; shipyards to see higher earnings driven by high- ASP orderbooks and lower steel prices; 2) orderbook regaining in 2029- 32E; pick up in new ship orders on replacement and stricter decarbonization. We believe Yangzijiang, the largest non- SOE shipyard in China, is well placed to benefit in the earnings booming stage; we expect \(20\%\) EPS CAGR in 2024- 28E (peak), with margins (EBIT margin \(>30\%\) ) and ROE \((>25\%)\) benefiting from higher- value containership orders and efficiency/cost advantage.

New orders to pick up from 26E: We attribute its new order market share loss in 1H25 to its tighter capacity (3.9- year orderbook) vs. Korea/Japan's c.3 years, and believe it will gain further market share from 2026E with capacity opening up post 2025 deliveries, especially with its new shipyard, Hongyuan, adding \(20\%\) capacity from mid- 26E. We believe the negative impact on China shipbuilding from higher USTR port fee is likely limited, as non- China operators have the flexibility to redeploy China- built vessels out of the US.

Valuation/ what's priced in: Our reverse valuation analysis suggests the current share price is largely pricing in the cash flows from the current orderbook + net cash; we expect pick- up in new orders to bring incremental upside. We see current valuation as attractive with Yangzijiang's above peers returns, lowest P/B and higher dividend yield. Our 12m TP of SGD 4.00 is based on P/B vs ROE (2.2x 2026E P/B derived from 21% cycle- average ROE).
Catalysts: Earnings beat & new orders share gain. Risks: Steel prices, US regulations on China- built vessels, newbuild prices.

Executive Summary4New orders pick-up from 2026E9Accelerating earnings growth in 2025-28E, Yangzijiang positioned to see the strong margins and returns as a cost leader13Key catalysts &amp; share price drivers17Valuation: Target price based on target P/B derived from cycle-average ROE20Financials: Earnings growth by +28% CAGR in 2025-27E driving ROE to 28%23Key risks25Disclosure Appendix27

As discussed in our Global Shipbuilding sector note, we are positive on the shipbuilding industry in China, currently expecting a longer upcycle, and already having witnessed an Orderbook surge stage in 2021- 24. We categorize the remaining upcycle into the following stages:

Earnings uplift stage in 2025- 28E: We expect the new ship orders to fall to the levels in 2022- 23, which would drag down the orderbook and newbuild prices by only \(16\% /12\%\) from 2024 peak, given the current capacity is relatively tight with orderbook cover years maintaining above 2.5 years. Meanwhile, we expect shipyards would likely increasingly monetize their high- value orderbooks.

Orderbook regaining momentum in 2029- 32E: We expect new ship orders to materially pick up from 2029E driven by the replacement demand for an aging fleet and stricter decarbonization (for the ships to be delivered before 2035E), which would drive the orderbook backlog and newbuild prices back to 2024 peak.

We expand our coverage to the shipbuilding sub- sector and initiate coverage on Yangzijiang Shipbuilding (YAZG.SI) with a Buy rating. Yangzijiang Shipbuilding is a shipbuilding company headquartered in China and has been listed in Singapore since Apr- 2007. The company was founded by Ren Yuanlin, and is currently led by his son, Ren Letian, who was appointed as the CEO in May- 15 and Executive Chairman in Apr- 20. The Founder, Ren Yuanlin, owned \(22\%\) stake in the company as of Dec- 24. Yangzijiang had \(5\%\) market share in global shipyard capacity (CGT terms) as of 2024, with its shipyards located in Jingjiang city of Jiangsu Province. The company's major shipbuilding products include mid/large sized containerships, bulkers, and tankers. We believe the company has a relatively higher competitive advantage in the containership segment. The company also owns \(51\%\) stake in JV Yangzi Mitsui (YAMIC) which produces high- end gas carriers, and has recorded strong profitability. Yangzijiang's shipbuilding business has been able to achieve a \(13\%\) average net margin in the past 10 years, the highest among global peers, driven by its cost advantage.
We are Buy rated on Yangzijiang for three key reasons:

Firstly, we expect its new orders to pick up from 2026E, while we also expect its orderbook to remain flattish in 2025- 28E (Exhibit 4), better than the broader industry. We expect new orders to be driven by:

Relatively less tight capacity after one- year of muted new orders - As discussed in our sector note, we attribute China's market share loss in new ship orders in 1H25 to an extremely tight capacity with orderbook cover years of 3.7 years (Yangzijiang's 3.9 years) at end- 24, vs. Korea and Japan's at c.3

years. We forecast Yangzijiang's orderbook cover years to fall to 3.5 years by end- 2025E, after one- year of muted new order wins (GSe \(\) 2bn/0.7mn\(CGTs) in 2025, which we expect would leave more capacity for the company to bid for new orders in 2026E.

- Capacity expansion amid the ongoing long upcycle to help gain market share 
- Yangzijiang expects its Hongyuan (泓远) Shipyard to become operational by end-2026, which we estimate will add another \(20\%\) to its current capacity and help alleviate the tighter supply and help the company gain market share.

- Given a tighter capacity, Yangzijiang is able to be more selective on high-margin new orders 
- Among global shipyards, Yangzijiang has seen the longest orderbook cover years in the past 5 years, benefiting from its efficiency and long-term relationship with shippers.

- Limited negative impact from USTR 
- We believe the negative impact on Chinese shipbuilding, from higher US port service fee for China-built vessels, is likely limited, as non-China shipping operators have the flexibility to redeploy China-built vessels out of the US given only \(4\%\) of the international fleet calls at the US port were China-built or operated.

- As we discussed in our sector note, we categorize the ongoing upcycle into two stages going forward. For the earnings uplift stage in 2025-28E, we expect the new ship orders would return to the levels in 2022-23, which would drag down the orderbook and newbuild prices by only \(16\% /12\%\) from 2024 peak, given the capacity remains quite tight with orderbook cover years remaining above 2.5 years; at the same time, we also believe shipyards would accelerate their earnings growth during 2025-28E and see peak earnings in 2028E, driven by: 1) the orders won in 2024 with a record-high newbuild price; 2) the price of steel (accounting for \(30\%\) of operating cost) which has declined by \(40\%\) from 2021 peak.

- Among global peers, we believe Yangzijiang is an industry leader with superior margins and returns due to its competitiveness on high-margin orders and cost advantage. By comparing the unit cost among shipyards in China, Korea and Japan, we note that Chinese players' unit operating cost (per CGT) are \(\sim 50\%\) lower than Korean and Japanese peers, considering a much lower labor cost and steel price (20% lower). And among Chinese listed shipyards, Yangzijiang has recorded the lowest operating costs. In addition, Yangzijiang could also benefit from a lower interest rate given China's interest rate is currently lower than Korea.

- Yangzijiang's share price underperformed other Chinese and Korean peers in the past 12 months, mainly due to its muted new orders YTD and potential market concerns that USTR's higher port service fee on China-built vessels

would structurally make Chinese shipyards continuously lose market share. However, we believe the impact from USTR fees on China- built vessels is likely limited, and attribute the market share loss for Yangzijiang to its tighter capacity with much longer orderbook cover years, and we believe it will gain back market share from 2026E, which will be a key share price catalyst.

- Yangzijiang also has the lowest P/B vs. the highest ROE with the highest dividend yield among global peers for 2025-27E.- Based on our reverse valuation analysis, we believe the current share price is largely pricing in the cash flow from the existing orderbook and the current net cash position, which suggests any potential pick-up of new ship orders would bring incremental upside to the share price.

Share price drivers - based on our historical correlation, we observe that the share price is not only driven by orderbook backlog, but also driven by earnings beats, as the orderbook is a relevant measure for future revenue but the final earnings also depends on the costs (e.g. steel price) and operational efficiency. Especially for Chinese shipyards including Yangzijiang, for which the orderbook is capped by the capacity not the demand, we don't think current orderbook fairly reflects the company's long- term competitiveness and value. Yangzijiang's share price retreated since Apr- 2015 with the declining orderbook backlog, but saw a rebound from Oct- 2016 on likely strong earnings expectations from the delivery of high- value large containerships, and we expect earnings beat as a key share price driver in the near term (our 26/27E earnings estimates are 26- 39% above consensus (Exhibit 1), and we expect its new orders to materially pick from 2026.

We derive our 12- month target price of SGD 4.00 (upside \(+37\%\) ) based on P/B vs ROE valuation. We apply target P/B multiple of \(2.2x\) to our end- 2026 BVPS. We derive the target P/B based on the cycle- average (2025- 32E) ROE of \(21\%\) and Cost of Equity of \(10.2\%\) with long- term growth of \(1\%\) . We believe the average ROE of this cycle ahead till 2032E (as we discussed in sector note) fairly reflects the core value the company creates throughout a long cycle.

Our 26/27E earnings estimates are 26- 39% above consensus, driven by a higher EBIT margin expectation, as we forecast the orders that were signed in 2024 with higher margins to generate revenue in 2026- 27E.

We believe Yangzijiang's new orders would significantly pick up from 2026E, driven by its competitiveness in the long orderbook cover years, and we see limited impact from USTR's higher port service fee on China- built vessels. We attribute its market share loss in 2025E to capacity shortages. We see a less tight capacity after one- year of muted new order wins in 2025 would leave more capacity for the company to bid for new orders in 2026E, especially considering the capacity expansion (newly opened shipyard Hongyuan) amid this long upcycle would help Yangzijiang to gain market share. We also forecast its orderbook to remain flattish in 2025- 28E (Exhibit 4), better than the broader industry.

1) Less tight capacity after one-year of muted new order wins in 2025E - As discussed in our sector note, we attribute the China's market share loss of new ship orders in 1H25 to an extremely tight capacity with orderbook cover years of 3.7 years at end-24, vs. Korea and Japan's c.3 years. This case also applies to Yangzijiang, given its even longer orderbook cover years of 3.9 years. However, we believe the company likely did not proactively do marketing in 2025E as its current orderbook has already been scheduled to 2029. We forecast Yangzijiang's orderbook cover years to fall to 3.5 years by end-2025E, after one-year of muted new order wins (GSe 2bn/0.7mn CGTs) in 2025, which would leave more capacity for the company to bid for new orders in 2026E.

Yangzijiang will newly open Hongyuan (泓远) Shipyard in end- 2026, which we estimate will add another \(20\%\) to its current capacity and help alleviate the tighter supply and help the company gain further market share.

Among Chinese shipyards, Yangzijiang has seen the longest orderbook cover years compared to global peers in the past 5 years, benefiting from its efficiency and long- term relationship with shippers. Especially Yangzijiang has a proven track record in winning higher- margin alternative- fuel ship orders (required by decarbonization regulations), with a much higher market share in these orders vs. its capacity market share.

We believe the negative impact on Chinese shipbuilding from higher US port service fee for China- built vessels is likely limited, as non- China shipping operators have the flexibility to redeploy China- built vessels out of the US given only \(4\%\) of the international fleet calls at the US port were China- built or operated as of 2024. We believe technology and USTR impact could mainly change the new order preference for gas carriers (especially LNG carriers), potentially to Korean shipyards considering its larger exposure to the US, and Korean shipyards' relative technological advantage (shorter production time).

We think the key factor for recent share loss for Chinese shipyards is China's orderbook cover years (3.7 years) is significantly higher, namely as the capacity is relatively tight, compared to Korea and Japan. As such, we believe once the orderbook for China relatively declines or Chinese shipyards capacity expands, China Shipbuilders could gain further market share, in our view. In fact, the June and July new ship orders indicate a rise in China shipbuilders' market share, with \(69\%\) in these two months vs. \(49\%\) in 5M25.

We observe that the share price for Yangzijiang has not only been driven by the orderbook backlog, but also driven by earnings beats, as the orderbook can determine the future revenue but the final earnings also depends on the cost (e.g. steel price) and operational efficiency. Especially for Yangzijiang for which the orderbook is capped by the capacity not the demand, we don't think current orderbook fairly reflects its long- term competitiveness and value.

As we discussed in our sector note, we categorize the ongoing upcycle into two stages going forward. For the earnings uplift stage in 2025- 28E, we expect the new ship orders would return to the levels in 2022- 23, which would drag down the orderbook and newbuild price by only \(16\% /12\%\) from 2024 peak, given the capacity is remains relatively tight with orderbook cover years remaining above 2.5 years; at the same time, we also believe Yangzijiang would increasingly monetize its high- value orderbook with earnings growth acceleration.

We expect earnings growth acceleration for Yangzijiang driven by: 1) the orders wins in 2024 with record- high newbuild prices; 2) the price of steel (accounting for \(30\%\) of operating cost), which has declined by \(40\%\) from 2021 peak.
Among global peers, we see Yangzijiang as an industry leader with its superior margins and returns due to its cost advantage.

We attribute Yangzijiang's highest margins and returns to its: a) Competitiveness in the high- margin orders; and b) Cost advantage.

Yangzijiang, as a cost leader - By comparing the unit cost among shipyards in China, Korea and Japan in 2024, we note that Chinese players' unit operating cost (per CGT) have been \(\sim 50\%\) lower than Korean and Japanese peers, considering Chinese shipyards have much lower labor cost and the steel price was also \(20\%\) lower than Korea's and Japan's on avg. since 2021, while the ship equipment price has been similar and the increase has been slower than newbuild price. Key catalysts & share price driversYangzijiang's share price has underperformed Chinese and Korean peers in the last 12 months, mainly due to Yangzijiang's muted new orders 2025 YTD and potential market concerns that USTR's higher port service fee on China- built vessels would structurally make Chinese shipyards consistently lose market share. However, as we mentioned above, we believe the impact from USTR fees on China- built vessels is likely limited, and attribute the market share loss to China's much longer orderbook for forward cover years namely tighter capacity. We believe Yangzijiang will gain further market share from 2026E with earnings growth acceleration. Therefore, see significant upside potential to Yangzijiang's current valuation, especially considering its lowest P/B vs. the highest ROE with the highest dividend yield among major peers.

We derive our 12- month target price of SGD 4.00 (upside \(+37\%\) ) based on P/B vs ROE valuation. We apply target P/B multiple of \(2.2x\) to our end- 2026 BVPS. We derive the target P/B based on the cycle- average (2025- 32E) ROE of \(21\%\) and Cost of Equity of \(10.2\%\) with long- term growth of \(1\%\) . We believe the P/B valuation is suitable for shipbuilding industry given the cyclical nature and higher earnings volatility, and also think the average ROE of this cycle ahead till 2032E (as we discussed in sector note) could fairly reflect the core value the company throughout the long cycle.

We think the P/B valuation could be higher than historical range, as the company has switched its cash use from the previous high- risk but lower- return debt investment, to capacity expansion amid an upcycle and is focused on shareholder return improvement.

- Disposal of high-risk but lower-return debt investment: Yangzijiang had been involved in debt investment business by investing excess cash in short-term entrusted loans, via its investment segment before 2022. However, this business only delivered a ROE at mid-to-high single-digit, consistently lower than shipbuilding segment's ROE of double digit during 2013-2021; while occupied 53% of total book value in 2021. We believe this investment business materially dragged down the historical P/B valuation before 2022, with potential market concerns over Yangzijiang's cash use to a high-risk but lower-return business. The investment segment was spun off and separately listed in Singapore stock exchange in 2022.

Potential Capex for capacity expansion amid upcycle may help Yangzijiang gain further market share and improve cash returns: Instead of deploying cash to the debt investment, we believe Yangzijiang has sufficient cash to further invest in shipbuilding supply chain amid this upcycle, which could include the Capex for new shipyards, equity investment in shipyards and equipment factories. We think this potential use of cash could help create synergies and help Yangzijiang gain further market share and improve its returns.

Yangzijiang bought \(34\%\) stake in Tsuneishi Zhoushan Shipyard in Mar- 2025 with investment of Rmb833mn, and we estimate this investment would recognize Rmb336bn associate income in 2025E. Yangzijiang is expanding its capacity by \(20\%\) via the new opening (scheduled in mid- 2026) of Hongyuan Shipyard, of which the total budget is Rmb3bn. Yangzijiang also established a new subsidiary Yangzi Runze in Feb- 25, with manufacturing base located adjacent to YAMIC for potential development of clean- energy vessels. Though this project was suspended in mid- 2025, management noted it does not rule out the possibility of resumption of expansion plan in case of improvement in market dynamics.

DPS for 2025- 28 to rise at \(17\%\) CAGR. We believe the company has sufficient cash to improve shareholder return through share buyback and dividend. Though the company's dividend payout rate policy is \(30\% - 40\%\) , we expect the DPS for 2025- 28 to rise at \(17\%\) CAGR along with earnings growth acceleration. Moreover, management noted it does not rule out the possibility to further improve the company's dividend payout ratio.
Potential share buybacks: The company has spent Rmb165mn to repurchase \(0.377\%\) shares YTD 2025. However, we note the company has not provided any guidance on future share buybacks.

We do not include an M&A component in our target price methodology for the company, as we assign an M&A score of 3, indicating low probability of M&A (0- 15%). We see a low likelihood of the company being acquired, considering the volatile nature of the industry, and the company's long history as an independent shipbuilder (i.e., unaffiliated with any other larger entity).

Revenue: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding recognizes shipbuilding revenue over time based on construction progress. We expect revenue to grow by \(3\% /18\% /18\%\) in 2025- 27E, largely materializing ASP growth for contracts signed in 2022- 24 esp. for containerships.

Cost: We expect unit raw materials cost to decline by \(- 12\%\) YoY in 2025E benchmarking YTD China's shipbuilding steel plate trends, followed by \(+5\% / + 3\%\) YoY in 2026- 27E. That said, we continue to expect margin improvement driven by construction of containerships which generally have higher margins vs. tankers and bulkers. We expect depreciation to grow by \(6\% /11\% /10\%\) in 2025- 27E as Hongyuan Shipyard and LNG terminal construction is scheduled to complete by 1H26/1H27 respectively.

Investment income: We also expect higher earnings contribution from JV/Associates of Rmb1.0- 1.6bn in 2025- 27E (vs. Rmb559mn in 2024), reflecting Yangzijiang's acquisition of \(34\%\) stake in Tsuneishi Zhoushan yard in Mar- 2025, and earnings improvement in JV Yangzi Mitsui (YAMIC) on a strong orderbook backlog on high- end gas carriers with better profitability.

Net profit: As a result, we expect net profit to grow by \(+32\% / + 27\% / + 25\%\) YoY, or \(+28\%\) CAGR in 2025- 27E driving ROE to \(28\%\) by 2027E, vs. \(13\%\) ROE avg (for shipbuilding business) in past 10 years.

Balance sheet and cash flow statement: As of end 1H25, Yangzijiang Shipbuilding has a strong balance sheet with Rmb18bn net cash on hand (total cash of Rmb24bn and total debt of Rmb6bn), translating to net gearing ratio of \(- 66\%\) . We expect the company generate operating cash flow of Rmb 8- 14bn in 2025- 27E as it receives cash flow from new contract orders and final payments upon vessel deliveries. On Capex, we model Rmb2.2bn in 2025- 26E for Hongyuan Shipyard and LNG terminal construction. We expect the company to pay dividend of Rmb2.0/3.9/4.9bn in 2025- 27E based on \(38\%\) dividend payout ratio (in line with 2024). As a result, we project the company's net cash level to reach Rmb38bn by 2027E, with net gearing further improving to \(- 77\%\) (net cash).

Higher- than- expected steel prices: Steel plates generally accounts for around \(30\%\) of total operating cost in shipbuilding. In fact, China's steel plate price has been tracking at \(\sim 20\%\) discount compared to Japan and Korea's, driving superior margins for Yangzijiang Shipbuilding. In case of any steel price increase, especially considering China's anti- involution policy in steel sector, Yangzijiang Shipbuilding may see deterioration in margins and could negatively impact the company's earnings.

More stringent regulations from USTR on Chinese- built vessels: USTR has lowered additional US service fees on Chinese- built vessels in its Apr- version, which is incrementally less negative for Chinese- built vessels considering no fees for new ships on order. However, in case of more stringent regulations from USTR targeting Chinese- built vessels, this may divert new shipbuilding demand from Chinese shipyards to Korean and Japanese shipyards. This could negatively impact new order value received by Yangzijiang Shipbuilding each year, hence pose downside risks to our revenue estimates.

Larger- than- expected ASP decline: We currently expect new order ASP \((\) /CGT) to decline by \(2 - 4\%\) in 2025- 27E as forward cover years start to decline from 2025E. In case of larger- than- expected ASP decline, such as from higher competition in shipbuilding sector, or declining affordability from shipping companies, we could see downside risks to our revenue and margin estimates.

Faster- than- expected capacity expansion from other shipyards: In case of faster- than- expected capacity expansion from other shipyards, a higher shipbuilding capacity could drive less favorable S- D dynamics within shipbuilding sector and intensify competition. This could negatively impact Yangzijiang Shipbuilding's new order market share, and ASP received for new orders, hence lead to downside risk on our earnings estimates.

We derive our 12- month target price of SGD 4.00 based on P/B vs ROE valuation. We apply target P/B multiple of \(2.2x\) to our end- 2026 BVPS. We derive the target P/B based on the cycle- average (2025- 32E) ROE of \(21\%\) and Cost of Equity of \(10.2\%\) with long- term growth of \(1\%\) .

Key risks: 1) Higher- than- expected steel prices; 2) More stringent regulations from USTR targeting Chinese- built vessels; 3) Larger- than- expected ASP decline; 4) Faster- than- expected capacity expansion from other shipyards

We are Buy rated on Yangzijiang Shipbuilding. We expect the company's new orders to pick up from 2026E on 1) less tight capacity after one- year of muted new order wins in 2025E; 2) capacity expansion amid the ongoing upcycle to help in further market share gain; 3) competitiveness in high- margin orders, evidenced by its long orderbook cover years; and 4) limited negative impact from USTR. We believe Yangzijiang is well positioned given its cost advantage and superior returns in the earnings uplift stage of the ongoing upcycle. The stock is currently trading at \(\sim 2x\) P/B, higher than historical

average, however, we believe a higher P/B valuation vs. historical average is warranted given the company's focus on the Shipbuilding business (following spin off of its lower- return debt investment business, Yangzijiang Financial) with sufficient cash position for capacity expansion amid the upcycle and potential for improving shareholder return. Key catalysts: Earnings beat & new orders share gain.

The Goldman Sachs Factor Profile provides investment context for a stock by comparing key attributes to the market (i.e. our universe of rated stocks) and its sector peers. The four key attributes depicted are: Growth, Financial Returns, Multiple (e.g. valuation) and Integrated (a composite of Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple). Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple are calculated by using normalized ranks for specific metrics for each stock. The normalized ranks for the metrics are then averaged and converted into percentiles for the relevant attribute. The precise calculation of each metric may vary depending on the fiscal year, industry and region, but the standard approach is as follows:

Growth is based on a stock's forward- looking sales growth, EBITDA growth and EPS growth (for financial stocks, only EPS and sales growth), with a higher percentile indicating a higher growth company. Financial Returns is based on a stock's forward- looking ROE, ROCE and CROCI (for financial stocks, only ROE), with a higher percentile indicating a company with higher financial returns. Multiple is based on a stock's forward- looking P/E, P/B, price/dividend (P/D), EV/EBITDA, EV/FCF and EV/Debt Adjusted Cash Flow (DACF) (for financial stocks, only P/E, P/B and P/D), with a higher percentile indicating a stock trading at a higher multiple. The Integrated percentile is calculated as the average of the Growth percentile, Financial Returns percentile and (100% - Multiple percentile).

Financial Returns and Multiple use the Goldman Sachs analyst forecasts at the fiscal year- and at least three quarters in the future. Growth uses inputs for the fiscal year at least seven quarters in the future compared with the year at least three quarters in the future (on a per- share basis for all metrics).
For a more detailed description of how we calculate the GS Factor Profile, please contact your GS representative.

Across our global coverage, we examine stocks using an M&A framework, considering both qualitative factors and quantitative factors (which may vary across sectors and regions) to incorporate the potential that certain companies could be acquired. We then assign a M&A rank as a means of scoring companies under our rated coverage from 1 to 3, with 1 representing high (30%- 50%) probability of the company becoming an acquisition target, 2 representing medium (15%- 30%) probability and 3 representing low (0%- 15%) probability. For companies ranked 1 or 2, in line with our standard departmental guidelines we incorporate an M&A component into our target price. M&A rank of 3 is considered immaterial and therefore does not factor into our price target, and may or may not be discussed in research.
